metadata.titleEn: South-East Tibetan plateau Station of Chinese Academy of Sciences: basic meteorological data in the station (2019-2020)
metadata.description:
The meteorological data are the basic meteorological data such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, precipitation and air pressure observed in the observation field of Southeast Tibet station of Chinese Academy of Sciences (94.738286 ° e, 29.76562 ° n, 3326m), and the underlying surface is forest grassland. The time resolution of the original data is 10min, the air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and air pressure are calculated by arithmetic mean, and the precipitation is the daily cumulative value. The meteorological station was set up at the end of 2006 and the probes were replaced in August 2020. Please note that the models of instrument probes before and after the update are as follows: the model of temperature and humidity probe was changed from HMP45C to hmp155; The model of air pressure probe is changed from PTB220 to ptb110; The model of wind speed sensor is changed from 034b to 0513, and the model of rain gauge sensor is rg13h
The data can be used by students and researchers engaged in meteorology, atmospheric environment or ecology (Note: when using, it must be indicated in the article that the data comes from South East Tibetan Plateau station for integrated observation and research of alpine environment, CAS)
metadata.instructions: The file name is Southeast Tibet station day (2019-2020), in Excel format

background: In mountainous areas, different altitudes exhibit distinct vertical zonation due to variations in water (precipitation) and heat (temperature) components. The southeastern Tibet Sejila Mountain has a pronounced mountain vertical zonation characteristic: from the foot of the mountain to the summit, it includes broadleaf forest, mixed coniferous and broadleaf forest, coniferous forest, shrubs, and moss. The vegetation types in Sejila Mountain are rich, and the longevity of trees is notable (Lu et al., 2015). The tree line at 4390 m is one of the highest forest lines in the world, making it a hotspot for tree-ring and forest ecology research (Wang et al., 2014; Liang et al., 2016; Shen et al., 2018). Currently, there is limited research on the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain (Liang et al., 2011). Most studies by some scholars on the changes in temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in this region and its vicinity are based on the Baji Station (formerly Linzhi Station) and the nearby Bomi Station, focusing on the vertical lapse rate of temperature across the entire Tibetan Plateau (Jiang Jingchao et al., 2016; Guo et al., 2016; Li et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2001, 2018; Zhang et al., 2018) and precipitation gradients (Guo et al., 2016).
research objective: Therefore, this article explores the vertical variation patterns of temperature and precipitation on the eastern and western slopes of the Sejila Mountain based on temperature and precipitation data from 11 meteorological stations. This not only deepens the understanding of the influence of slope orientation on the vertical gradient changes of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain but also helps to better understand the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distribution with altitude changes. Additionally, it provides reliable data support for future hydrological modeling in this region.
challenges: Due to the many factors affecting the vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient, among the meteorological stations in the Sejila Mountains, except for the mountain pass station, tree line station, and ecological station located on the ridge, all other stations are situated in valley areas. Additionally, the western slope and high-altitude stations are relatively few, which may affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient obtained in this article.
methods: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation records (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bing Station, and Layue, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet and two stations at the tree line (as shown in Figure 1 and Table 1). Based on the geographical locations of these stations, the stations in the Sejila Mountain area are divided into two natural geographical units according to slope orientation: the west slope (south slope) and the east slope (north slope), with the Sejila Mountain Pass station belonging to both the west and east slopes. The vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient estimates are obtained through regression analysis based on the elevation of the stations and temperature or precipitation amounts.
dataset: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation values (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bing Station, and Layue, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet Station (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line.
findings: From 2013 to 2018, the average temperature lapse rate (λ) at 11 stations on the Selila Mountain ranged from 0.59 to 0.63 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ value in 2016 and the highest in 2014. The average λ from 2013 to 2018 was 0.60 °C·(100 m)^-1. The western slope had λ values ranging from 0.69 to 0.72 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ in 2016 and the highest in 2014, and an average λ of 0.71 °C·(100 m)^-1 from 2013 to 2018. The eastern slope had λ values between 0.53 and 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1; unlike the Selila Mountain and western slope, the lowest λ in the eastern slope occurred in 2015 and the highest in 2017, with an average λ of 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1 from 2013 to 2018. From 2013 to 2018, the average precipitation gradient on the eastern slope was 10.5 mm·(100 m)^-1, with a trend of precipitation increasing with altitude during the monsoon period, followed by a decrease and then an increase. In the non-monsoon period, the trend was a decrease followed by an increase, with a significant precipitation gradient above the southeastern Tibetan stations.

Verification.Question: Did the equipment used for collecting meteorological data at the site undergo any updates during the period 2019-2020?
Is the meteorological data suitable for use in atmospheric and ecological research according to the metadata?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the specific methods used to calculate temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in mountain regions?
Where are the meteorological stations located that provide data for analyzing the vertical gradient of temperature and precipitation in the southeastern Tibetan Plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: Bayi, Nichi, Station 114, Station 113, Mountain Pass, Ecological Station, Lulang, Military Station, Layue, South-East Tibetan plateau Station, treeline station

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection challenges are faced when studying temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous environments?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a method used to estimate temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a method used to estimate temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions involves collecting daily temperature and precipitation data from multiple meteorological stations at different altitudes. Regression analysis is then applied to determine the relationship between elevation and the observed weather parameters.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting accurate meteorological data in mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in collecting accurate meteorological data in mountainous regions is the limited number of high-altitude and ridge-top stations, which can affect the estimation of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients due to the station placement mostly in valley areas.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection methods used for recording basic meteorological data in alpine environments?
Feature Specification.Answer: sensors for temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, precipitation, atmospheric pressure, time resolution of 10 minutes, arithmetic averaging, daily cumulative precipitation, updated sensor models in 2020, improved data accuracy

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key challenges faced in collecting meteorological data from different altitudes in mountainous regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: placement of stations mostly in valleys, potential inaccuracies in temperature lapse rates, potential inaccuracies in precipitation gradients, limited number of high-altitude stations, varying factors influencing temperature gradients, varying factors influencing precipitation gradients

Quantification.Question: What is the time resolution of the original meteorological data collected at the South-East Tibetan plateau Station?
What is the average annual temperature lapse rate (λ) for the Sejila Mountains from 2013 to 2018?

Definition.Question: What does '气温垂直递减率' mean in the context of meteorological data collection on mountain slopes?
Definition.Answer: In the context of meteorological data collection on mountain slopes, '气温垂直递减率' refers to the vertical temperature gradient, which is the rate at which temperature decreases with an increase in altitude. It is calculated by regression analysis of temperature against altitude at different meteorological stations.

Definition.Question: How is '气象数据的时间分辨率' defined in meteorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: '气象数据的时间分辨率' is defined as the time interval at which meteorological data is collected or recorded. In the context provided, the original meteorological data has a time resolution of 10 minutes, meaning measurements are taken every 10 minutes.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods at the 中科院藏东南站 for meteorological data compare to those used in the 色季拉山气象站点 in terms of temporal and spatial resolution?
Comparison.Answer: The 中科院藏东南站 collects basic meteorological data with a temporal resolution of 10 minutes, while the 色季拉山气象站点 use daily values for temperature and precipitation from several stations. In terms of spatial resolution, the 中科院藏东南站 is focused on a single location, whereas the 色季拉山气象站点 data are collected from 11 stations, providing a broader spatial coverage.

Interpretation.Question: What are the challenges and limitations faced when estimating precipitation gradients in mountainous regions, and how might these affect the interpretation of hydrological data?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in estimating precipitation gradients in mountainous regions include the limited number of high-altitude stations and the positioning of most stations in valleys rather than ridges. These factors can affect the accuracy of precipitation gradient estimates, potentially leading to biases in understanding the hydrological behavior and water resource management in these areas.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the observed climate data from multiple stations be utilized to enhance the accuracy of hydrological models in alpine environments?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed climate data from multiple stations, including temperature and precipitation records, provide a comprehensive dataset for analyzing vertical climate gradients. This data can improve the accuracy of hydrological models by offering reliable input parameters that reflect the spatial variability of climatic factors, crucial for simulating watershed hydrology in alpine environments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary factors that influence the accuracy and reliability of meteorological data collection in high-altitude, alpine environments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges include the location of meteorological stations primarily in valleys, which may not provide a complete picture of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients. Additionally, the limited number of high-altitude stations on the western slope could affect the accuracy of derived temperature and precipitation gradients.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes variations in temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients across different slopes of mountainous regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors contributing to these variations include the orientation of slopes (eastern vs. western), which affects temperature and precipitation patterns due to different exposure to climatic elements. The study found differences between the eastern and western slopes of Sejila Mountain, with variations in annual temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients influenced by monsoon and non-monsoon periods.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on data accuracy when replacing older meteorological sensors with new models at a high-altitude observation station?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Replacing older meteorological sensors with new models at a high-altitude observation station can potentially improve data accuracy by providing more reliable and precise measurements. However, it could also introduce inconsistencies in the data series due to differences in sensor specifications and calibration processes, requiring careful calibration and validation to ensure continuity in long-term datasets.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of having a limited number of high-altitude meteorological stations on the accuracy of estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Having a limited number of high-altitude meteorological stations can reduce the accuracy of estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients because it limits the data available for regression analyses, potentially skewing results. This scarcity can lead to underrepresentation of certain altitudinal zones and may result in less reliable estimates of these climatic parameters, affecting the understanding of ecological and hydrological processes in mountainous regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting basic meteorological data, such as temperature and precipitation, at different altitudes and locations in the southeastern Tibetan plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to understand the vertical variation patterns of temperature and precipitation on the eastern and western slopes of Sejila Mountain, which helps in better understanding the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distribution with altitude changes. It also provides reliable data support for hydrological modeling in this region in the future.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to consider the replacement of sensor models when collecting meteorological data over extended periods?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to consider the replacement of sensor models because changes in equipment, such as temperature, humidity, or pressure sensors, can affect the accuracy and consistency of the data. Understanding these changes ensures the integrity and reliability of the long-term data analysis for meteorological, atmospheric environment, or ecological research.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are necessary to ensure the accurate calibration of various meteorological sensors when collecting meteorological data in alpine environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures involve replacing and updating the sensor probes, as was done in 2020 when the temperature and humidity probe model was changed from HMP45C to HMP155, the pressure probe from PTB220 to PTB110, and the wind speed sensor from 034B to 0513, ensuring the accuracy and reliability of the data collected.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers estimate temperature vertical lapse rates and precipitation gradients using geographically distributed meteorological stations in mountainous regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers conduct regression analysis using the elevation of meteorological stations along with temperature and precipitation data to estimate the vertical lapse rates and gradients. The data from various stations on different slopes are used to analyze the vertical changes in temperature and precipitation, as demonstrated by dividing the stations into western and eastern slope units according to their geographic location.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or technological changes enabled the effective replacement of meteorological sensors at high-altitude research stations?
Enablement.Answer: The replacement of meteorological sensors at high-altitude research stations was facilitated in 2020 when the instruments at the South-East Tibetan plateau Station for integrated observation and research of alpine environment were upgraded. Temperature and humidity sensors were updated from HMP45C to HMP155, pressure sensors from PTB220 to PTB110, and wind speed sensors from 034B to 0513, while the rain gauge sensor (RG13H) remained unchanged. These technological upgrades likely improved data accuracy and reliability.

Enablement.Question: What are the challenges and enabling factors in using regression analysis for estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous areas?
Enablement.Answer: One challenge in using regression analysis for estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous areas is the uneven distribution of meteorological stations, with some located in valleys and others on ridges, which may affect the accuracy of estimates. However, having multiple data points from various elevations and slopes, as seen in the dataset from Linzhi City meteorological stations and Tibetan plateau stations, enables regression analysis by providing diverse data points that can be used to model the relationships between altitude and climatic variables.

Expectation.Question: Why is there an expectation for diverse environmental conditions to affect the vertical temperature gradient and precipitation gradient in mountainous regions?
Expectation.Answer: Due to the differences in water (precipitation) and thermal (temperature) components across altitudes, mountainous regions like the South-East Tibetan Plateau exhibit distinct vertical zones, affecting the temperature and precipitation gradients.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in accurately estimating vertical temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients with limited high-altitude meteorological stations?
Expectation.Answer: The limited number of high-altitude stations, such as those on the western slope of Sejila Mountain, coupled with most stations being located in valleys, may impact the accuracy of the estimated temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using arithmetic averages for meteorological data like temperature, humidity, wind speed, and pressure collected at 10-minute intervals?
Judgmental.Answer: Using arithmetic averages for meteorological data can provide a simplified view of the conditions over a period, which is useful for identifying general trends. However, it may overlook short-term variations and extreme events, which could be significant in understanding local climate dynamics and variability. The choice of averaging method should be carefully considered based on the research objectives and the nature of the data.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in accurately estimating vertical temperature and precipitation gradients across different geographical units, such as the eastern and western slopes of a mountain range?
Judgmental.Answer: Estimating vertical temperature and precipitation gradients can be challenging due to the variability in microclimates, differences in station locations (such as ridge versus valley), and the limited number of high-altitude stations. These factors can introduce uncertainties in the gradient estimations, and the presence of diverse environmental conditions across slopes could further complicate the analysis.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how could future data collection efforts be improved to provide more comprehensive support for hydrological modeling in mountainous regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Future data collection efforts could benefit from increasing the number of meteorological stations, especially at higher altitudes and diverse locations, to capture a broader range of environmental conditions. Additionally, integrating remote sensing technologies and deploying advanced sensors could enhance data resolution and accuracy. Collaborative efforts with local agencies and leveraging historical data might also improve the foundational dataset for hydrological modeling.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can ensure accurate meteorological readings in mountainous regions.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection methods in mountainous regions can face challenges due to varying altitudes and environmental conditions. In the field, meteorological data such as temperature, humidity, wind speed, precipitation, and pressure are collected using specialized sensors. These sensors are often placed in strategic locations to capture accurate readings, and the data is averaged or accumulated over specific intervals to ensure reliability. However, factors like the location of stations (e.g., ridge versus valley) and sensor calibration (e.g., changing sensor models) can impact data accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the factors that influence the vertical temperature lapse rate in this type of mountainous environment.
Assertion.Answer: In mountainous environments, the vertical temperature lapse rate is influenced by several factors, including altitude, slope orientation, and atmospheric conditions. For instance, in the South-East Tibetan plateau, different slopes (west and east) exhibit varying temperature lapse rates due to differences in solar radiation exposure and atmospheric circulation patterns. The altitude of measurement stations and their specific location (e.g., ridge or valley) also play crucial roles in determining the temperature lapse rate observed.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how researchers overcome the challenge of limited high-altitude weather stations when studying precipitation gradients.
Assertion.Answer: Researchers often face challenges due to the limited number of high-altitude weather stations, which can affect the accuracy of precipitation gradient studies. To overcome this, they utilize data from multiple stations across varying altitudes and orientations to perform regression analysis, which helps estimate the precipitation gradients. Additionally, integrating data from other accessible nearby stations and considering natural geographic units (e.g., different slopes) can provide a more comprehensive understanding, despite the limited number of high-altitude observations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential challenges faced during the data collection process of meteorological variables such as temperature, humidity, wind speed, precipitation, and pressure in mountainous regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include factors affecting temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients due to the varied locations of meteorological stations, with most located in valleys and fewer on the western slope and high-altitude areas. This could affect the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methods used to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients based on the elevation and geographical positioning of meteorological stations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients are estimated through regression analysis based on the elevation and geographical locations of the stations, divided into natural geographical units of the western and eastern slopes of the region.
